paper_abstract: The repetition threshold introduced by Dejean and Brandenburg is the smallest real number alpha such that there exists an infinite word over a k-letter alphabet that avoids beta-powers for all beta > alpha. We extend this notion to colored graphs and obtain the value of the repetition thresholds of trees and "large enough" subdivisions of graphs for every alphabet size.
paper_title: REPETITION THRESHOLDS FOR SUBDIVIDED GRAPHS AND TREES
